DEFINITION: Autopsy; an examination and dissection of a dead body to determine cause of death or the changes produced by disease.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.
A small volume of blood removed for testing or storage.
The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.
A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.
The removal of tissue or fluid with a thin needle for examination under a microscope.

The removal of a tissue sample using a specially-designed endoscope consisting of a slender flexible forceps with movable cup-shaped jaws. The jaws are closed around the tissue to be collected and while closed the forceps are withdrawn to capture the biopsy tissue.
A surgical procedure in which part of a lesion is removed for microscopic examination.
Surgical removal of lymph nodes, usually done to assess the spread of cancer.: A lymph node that drains lymph from a region of interest.
Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.
Not provided or available.
Not stated explicitly or in detail.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Surgical excision of all or part of the pancreas and duodenum.
Removal of a disk of skin tissue, for microscopic examination, using a punch.
A surgical procedure to remove the remaining abnormal tissues from the body, not completely removed in an earlier attempt.

Surgical removal and examination of the sentinel node, the lymph node which is first in receiving the lymphatic drainage of a specified anatomic location and is most likely to be affected by the lymphatic spread of cancer.
Removal skin tissue, for microscopic examination, using a blade oriented in the horizontal plane of the skin surface.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.
Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.
